posts.name: Arjun Bhatia
posts.cooked:
We are looking for a robot cart to replace our cheap hardware store dolly. It works fine, but it does not have a handle and the casters have a hard time on gravel or uneven pavement (which we often encounter at event load-in). Looking for something we can buy off the shelf. Not looking to build a SuperCart, just something light and compact.

Our main requirements are as follows:

Has a handle extending upward, which we can push to maneuver the cart

Folds flat (we do not have a trailer or van, just 1-2 SUVs for load-in/out)

Lightweight enough to be easily lifted by one high school student (~10 kg)

Allowed on the field as per 2025 E706

Width of ~16" (so swerve wheels overhang on the sides and we can test the drivetrain before matches)

Load rating of at least 300 lbs

Soft budget of $250 CAD (~$175 USD)

Nice-to-haves:

Lift platform (I doubt this exists with the the size, weight, and price requirements above)

All four casters being swivel so we can more easily move the bot around the pit (most carts I see are two fixed, two swivel)

Some candidates we have right now:

Cosco shifter folding hand truck

VEVOR aluminum hand truck, 400 lbs load (2-in-1) - this seems quite flimsy and I doubt it can support 400 lbs in the middle when extended

Would love to hear what others have in mind. Also any reviews of our candidates or other people’s recommendations. While we are in Canada, if you can provide a certain style of cart, we can try to find an equivalent here.

link_counts.title: Shifter Multi-Position Folding Hand Truck and Cart - Cosco

VEVOR Aluminum Hand Truck, 2 in 1, 400 lbs Load Capacity, Heavy Duty Industrial Convertible Folding Hand Truck and Dolly, Utility Cart Converts from Hand Truck to Platform Cart with Rubber Wheels | VEVOR CA

posts.name: Chris Maupin
posts.cooked: Costco sells an upgraded version of the Cosco hand truck you have listed.  We have used that for the last 3 years to great success. It was so nice, we bought another to take our demo bot to fairs as well. https://www.costco.com/cosco-4-in-1-convertible-hand-truck.product.4000119325.html

2910 Cart CAD Release Technical

Not in your budget but 2910 cart is really good. We made a replica last year and it is really good

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked:
A bit of advice on casters - do NOT go cheap. You will likely want at least 5-6" wheels and ~4x+ the load capacity of your actual weights. MAYBE 4" if you go with more premium wheels and bearings.

I get that you want it to fit into the back of an SUV, but you’ll probably use the cart for a lot more than just the robot for load in/out. Rolling over door thresholds is going to be a problem if you buy the cheap 2" hardware store casters. Every year I see a team break cheap casters at a competition.

For a lift, we used a Harbor Freight ATV/UTV winch and some delrin blocks for slides on a fixed frame. The forks slide up and down the frame. The winch is 12VDC which is conveniently the same as a robot battery. (we also put an inverter in the cart to power a laptop charger for the control station.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
There’s two ways to head here.  One route is JUST to move the robot.  The other one is a work platform for the robot that also moves the robot.

For the first one, you can modify a hand truck with an extended foot that fits between the robot wheels.  You may need to add a tapered block on the back so that when you stab under the robot the tapered bit means there is only a tiny clearance under the belly pan+bumpers next to the hand truck.  Then, when you break it over, the back wheels end up farther off the ground.  Here’s a FANCY one.  Note that the extension folds, which is pretty important for stuffing it in a car… image 960×720 97.1 KB This one was a bit too wimpy, later upgraded some.  The kiddos really haven’t used either version. image 537×788 66.5 KB This looks promising:

image 960×720 97.1 KB

image 960×720 97.1 KB

image 537×788 66.5 KB

image 537×788 66.5 KB

Vergo Industrial Convertible Hand Truck - AS7A2 Heavy Duty Aluminum 3 in 1 Dolly (750 lb Capacity) Lightweight Frame, Ergonomic Handle, Extendable Loop, Versatile Moving Dolly (3 Positions, 53" High) - Amazon.com

$249.00

If you get the kind of hand truck with a set of casters part way up, you can use it for other things too…

For the cart, +1 on the BIG and strong wheels!  If you make the footprint really small its a pain to get over the cable protectors.  I definitely messed that part up…  I used a Vevor motorcycle jack platform to get height adjustment, four tiny Lowes toolboxes for “stuff”, two battery slots, and an inverter.  It needs to be bigger; as long as a robot.  Maybe wider too, but longer for -sure-. image 602×1001 97.5 KB

image 602×1001 97.5 KB

image 602×1001 97.5 KB

Stackers are a sorta-in between option.  Think hand-powered forklift.  The outriggers keep it from needing to tip to pick the load.  Kinda heavy and hard to transport, though.  They make hydraulic versions too.  You could cut things down to get the whole thing shorter. image 720×720 46.1 KB

image 720×720 46.1 KB

image 720×720 46.1 KB

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
ABhatia:

Nice-to-haves:

Lift platform (I doubt this exists with the the size, weight, and price requirements above)

Having a lift on a cart is a really nice-to-have feature.  Keep the robot low for load/unload and transportation while having it nice and high for inspection and maintenance.

Here’s an option from the USA that gets close to most of your specs.

Franklin Hydraulic Table Cart

It has a handle

It does not fold flat, but the handle and foot pump lever are easily removable for transportation

It is not lightweight - not sure why lifting with a single student is a requirement - there are always going to be at least two students around for lifting the robot

The cart itself meets the size requirements for going on the field, although with the foot pump lever attached, it becomes 37.25" long.  I don’t think anyone would prohibit this cart from going on the field, but if necessary, the pump lever can be easily left in the pit for 100% compliance.

Width is 17.75"

Load rating is 500 lb

Cost is USD 250

posts.name: Everett33
posts.cooked: While shopping around, be aware that the caster wheels can also be too large of a diameter on a robot cart. We currently use this ULine cart with 8" wheels and it rolls around too easy, because the cart and robot only weigh 220 pounds combined. It rolls so easy that our robot almost didn’t make it back to Michigan in one piece after Champs this year because it started to roll away while on the loading dock. Luckily a 1023 mentor chased it down before total chaos occurred.
